I have no idea what my money will be worth with all the Federal Reserve monetary manipulation going on.  I yearn for security.  That means staying put - job-wise.

Many tech companies encourage telecommuting these days, to save operational costs. Individuals or a couple who have a house in a good location, kids in god schools, community connections, etc. don't need the disruption of a move.
Conversely, many folks with fewer in-demand skills, or manufacturing and service industry background cannot move in search of better opportunities, mainly because of mortgages and health care.
- govts could lower tax rates substantially and remove mortgage interest deductions, which would make home ownership more fluid and rational
- govts could untie health insurance from employers/jobs, which would improve mobility, especially for the highly skilled and entrepreneurs. But, universal healthcare is a political mess, so that'll take time.

There were three new technologies hat developed in the late 1800 that could not have been developed without the other that made everything else possible.
Metallurgy
power generation
internal engine
Advancements in Metallurgy made it possible to make steel that had greater strength that was used to make a furnace that were needed to mass produce steel which made it affordable to buy and be used.
Because steel was stronger and more important less brittle and cheaper it was as used to manufacture beams that were used to build tall buildings.
This new stronger steel was needed to build a internal combustion engine that was smaller and lighter.
The airplane could not have been invented without this improved engine.
The new furnace made it possible to power machines that can produce electricity at a reduced price.
Tom Edison needed this to make it affordable to use his new light bulbs.
This is why he went into the electrical generating business.
Without these three things practically everything else could not have been built and used
Roebling could not have built the Brooklyn Bridge, Henry Ford could not build his model T, the Wright brothers could not invent the airplane Otis couldn't invent the modern elevator or Sullivan build tall buildings and Tom Edison's light bulb could not be used.

Back in the mid-90s, American historian Henry Steele Commager stated in an interview with Bill Moyers that our nation was at risk of never again seeing great politicians, statement, and presidents like Thomas Jefferson, John Adams, Alexander Hamilton, James Madison, Benjamin Franklin, and Abraham Lincoln, among others.

Commager said that the most brilliant minds of our century who could profoundly shape our country for the greater good now would never subject themselves to the ugliness and vitriol of contemporary politics. Many of the greatest minds of our time who could lead us are instead in industry, science, and academia. They will not allow their lives to be twisted apart, every fiber scrutinized, nor will they bear the lies and mudslinging of politics today. As a result, the American people have lost these great leaders and instead end up with charlatans and fools, those who can buy their way to the top, narcissistic billionaires who have no vision of America's true potential, and candidates who have no knowledge of domestic or foreign affairs, including the delicate geopolitics of the world. We, the people, are the losers.

The Democrats need to overhaul their candidate selection for President by eliminating the undemocratic caucus system. In Nebraska, Sanders got 15 delegates to Clinton's 10 by winning the caucus by 57% to 43%. When they had a non-binding primary election Nebraska, where many times more people voted, Clinton won by 57% to 43%. In Washington, Sanders won the caucuses, Sanders won 73% to 27% and was awarded 25 delegates to Clinton's 9. Tonight there is a non-binding primary in Washington. Last report with 75% of the vote in (with 30 times more than the votes of the caucuses), Hillary was ahead 54% to 46%. Interesting what happens when you have a real election. If the caucuses had been primaries, Hillary would be about 31 more pledged delegates ahead of Sanders than she is. How many more delegates would she be ahead if all the caucuses had been actual primary elections?

Interestingly, it's hard to even find the results for these two non-binding primaries in Nebraska and Washington. MSNBC has reported them on air, but the Times doesn't seem to be reporting either of them. (If I were a Sanders supporter and the facts were reversed, I'd say it's a conspiracy to cover up how undemocratic the DNC is and how my candidate is being cheated.) I know Bernie thinks he needs to change the Democratic primary rules, but I haven't hear him whining about how undemocratic the caucuses are.

"Just retrain" has to be the stupidest and most clueless idea I've heard in my lifetime.

I've probably "retrained" 3 or 4 times now. Didn't do me any good. I'm earning about the same in ACTUAL dollars (not inflation adjusted dollars) as I did in 1996. Every time I retrained...so did millions of others in my field or with my same degree. Now there were too many of us, all wanting the same not-very-good paying jobs in shrinking fields. And we had to compete -- at 40, 45, 50 -- with young attractive people right out of college.

Telling a 55 year old auto worker to "retrain" to become a computer programmer is cruel and unfeeling. He may have no aptitude for it. It will take years, and cost him a lot in lost wages and loans for tuition. At the end, he is now a 59 year old ex-autoworker.....trying to compete with 24 year olds in a shrinking job market (programming can be done very nicely in India, for $10K a year).

The number of "growing" fields is surprisingly small and most of these require advanced degrees, meaning tens of thousands in cost. By the time you GET the degree, the marker has moved and suddenly the field you studied and spent your life savings to learn....isn't "hot" anymore.

I have a pretty bad feeling about what will happen, in 2020-2025 to all those freshly minted "STEM" graduates....all hitting the market place at the same time.

Economists have never been in touch with the realities of people, and for this reason America has been suffering untold hardships. NAFTA, all the free trade agreements, China's joining the WTO... Economists said that lots of people would lose jobs, but that they'd just retrain and relocate anywhere, any time, to new jobs that were hiring, and ultimately generate more economic value in the process. Family? Friends? Sense of well-being? What are those things?!? Economists have never heard of such concepts. So here we are today, no factories, no stable employment. Thanks economists!

The 50th number that is the sum of two distinct powers of two:

Dealing exclusively with powers of 2 suggests we look at base-2 numbers which are bit strings of 1s or 0s since every bit placement is a sequental power of 2 (and since in this specific problem the powers are distinct the ambiguity introduced by adding two identical numbers that make their sum the next higher number is avoided).

So, since we are asked for the 50th number, we must therefore do a count on the ascending sequence of consecutive integers each having two and only two "on" bits in binary form -- "2-bit strings", as they were.

Consider the first 10 sequential two-bit binary numbers (i.e., containing only bit pairs):

----11

---101
---110

--1001
--1010
--1100

-10001
-10010
-10100
-11000

The recursive pattern is evident. Each grouping of strngs of n bit pairs thus contains n - 1 binary numbers (the 2-bit strings) in that group.

In the above example the number list count 10 = 4*5/2 is also the sum of the first 4 sets of consecutive 2-bit integers, and each member of the last group is a string 5 bits long.

Since the 50th number is asked for, and the cumulative number of bit strings (as each group sequence is formed) goes like 1 3 6 10 15 21 28 36 45 55, the 50th number must therefore be an 11 bit string. The 46th string is 10000000001, so the 50th is 100000010000 which is 2^11 + 2^5 = 2080.

He insisted that his wife ALWAYS keep a handgun in the glove compartment of their car for personal protection. Whenever they left the car, Vera transferred the handgun to her purse, also for reasons of protection. He opposed restrictions limiting law-abiding citizens from owning guns. I can surmise what Nabokov would have made of those road signs. Facts are stubborn things, aren't they?
